user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of irq:
```c
static int irq(void)
{
	int rc = 0;
	char *err_msg="";
	enum metal_log_level mll= metal_get_log_level();
	int i, tst_irq[2];

	/* Do not show LOG_ERROR or LOG_DEBUG for expected fail case */
	metal_set_log_level(METAL_LOG_CRITICAL);

	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		/* we only want to test the lib API, so create 'virtual' IRQs */
		tst_irq[i] = eventfd(0,0);
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s: irq %d associated with fd %d\n",
			  __func__, i, tst_irq[i]);
	}

	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[1], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 1 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}

	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 after unregistering failed\n";
		goto out;
	}
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[1]);

out:
	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		close(tst_irq[i]);
	}
	metal_set_log_level(mll);
	if ((err_msg[0] != '\0') && (!rc))
		rc = -EINVAL;
	if (rc) metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s", err_msg);
	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function irq:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
static int irq_handler(int irq, void *priv)
{
	(void)irq;
	(void)priv;

	return 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the shown conditional assignment appears to be unreachable: err_msg is initialized to the empty string and every assignment that makes err_msg non-empty is done only in branches where rc is non-zero (those branches immediately goto out). Therefore the conjunction (err_msg[0] != '\0') && (!rc) cannot be true. Other code constructs in the function are reachable via normal flow or via the error goto out path (the out: cleanup block is reachable both from error goto and normal fall-through), so they do not appear to violate the unreachable-code rule. The irq_handler and the metal_log macro are invoked or expanded under conditions that do not introduce unreachable code in this function, so they do not need investigation for Rule 2.1 in this context.
